captions.text:
The final novel in
my Jacques McKeown trilogy,

Will Leave the
Galaxy for Good, is now available

on audible.com. Tell them
Yahtzee sent ya. They won&#39;t care.
Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Sometimes I lick the underbellies of sugar 
gliders for an illicit sexual thrill. See,

First impressions DO matter. And first 
impressions of Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2 weren&#39;t

great because it&#39;s only got one save slot. One. 
Of all the trillions of numbers that exist,

they picked the very worst. Fuck&#39;s sake. 
What year is it? Tennis For Two had one

save slot as long as you kept the oscilloscope 
turned on. Then again, while I had to go Steam

folder spelunking to find and delete editor 
Nick&#39;s cloud save file from my hard drive,

that sort of thing always makes my PC gamer 
dick hard, so I went into Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2 with

renewed self-confidence, assured that the one save 
slot issue would never come up again. This is a

literary device we call &quot;foreshadowing.&quot; So it&#39;s 
been a yonk and a half since Dragon&#39;s Dogma 1,

and I only remember two things about it: 
the whole Pawn mechanic where you build an

NPC helper and hire them out to other players 
while hiring two helpers from other players,

which felt unsettlingly like the midpoint 
between enslaving the mentally subnormal and

sex trafficking, and a rather amusing &quot;climb 
all over giant monsters&quot; mechanic that meant

I spent more time than is comfortable with 
my face buried in a minotaur&#39;s pubic hair.

And Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2 brings back both of those, 
yay/boo depending on your personal pube interest.

Actually it brings back quite a lot from the 
previous game, even the title screen forgot to

put a 2 on the end, which led to a confused alt 
tab moment to make sure I hadn&#39;t mis-clicked my

Steam list. But the plot&#39;s developed. After 
heroically tanking all those pubes in the

first game the Arisen, that&#39;s you, has been made 
king of the realm. Which is refreshing. I mean,

Link saves the kingdom every fucking weekened, 
he&#39;s never been made king. The most he got in

a sequel was a faceful of dirt and transformation 
into a beansprout. So the Arisen gets to be King

and what marks the Arisen is that they have 
the ability to command the Pawns, who seem

to be the majority of the population judging 
by how many I randomly run into on the road,

so when you think about it it&#39;s kind of a 
roundabout form of democracy. But things

go to shit when a scheming queen replaces the 
Arisen with a looky-like and sells the original

to slavery in a foreign land. And thus begins 
the adventure of Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2, although

the initial situation is resolved in the first 
half hour by walking out of the foreign land,

back to the capital and very obviously being 
the Arisen. The rest is, y&#39;know, paperwork.

The story might sound full of epic themes 
and intrigue but it&#39;s being pushed through

the filter of the characters, and that&#39;s like 
pushing a hearty steak dinner through a tennis

racket. Most of the time you&#39;re only ever 
around pawns, who are a bunch of tiresome

suckups exclusively communicating in robotic 
repetitions of the patently bloody obvious.

&quot;You are running low on backpack space. Having 
backpack space means you can carry more things.

You are striking me about the head and face with 
a blunt object. This will ensure I sustain severe

brain damage. Truly the wisdom of the Arisen 
knows no slib blurble glop.&quot; Except imagine

all of this with every other word replaced 
with &quot;aught&quot; as a sort of cheat sheet madlib

version of Shakespearean dialect. Not that 
the ostensibly non-pawn NPCs do much better

on the AI front. Dragon&#39;s Dogma has ambitions 
to be a systems-driven Skyrim-like open world,

and such things tend to be admirable from a broad 
viewpoint but fall apart in the small details.

So I&#39;d see a palace guard resolutely staring 
into a space as three feet away a noblewoman

furiously pogos up and down in a futile 
attempt to bypass a waist-high railing.

But who cares what&#39;s going in castle town, 
let&#39;s go adventure. &quot;Good idea, Yahtzee,

now here&#39;s three critical path missions where 
you have to sneak into the castle and collect

incriminating evidence.&quot; You seriously 
expect me to sneak, now, game? No really,

I&#39;m actually asking, because I walked straight 
into the castle and most of the guards didn&#39;t seem

to give a shit. They attacked me at one point, but 
then so did the pig farmer I met on the way out,

which I eventually put down to the fact that 
my character had unsheathed their weapon.

And I didn&#39;t even ask him to, he automatically 
pulled them out whenever I did a dodge dash and

I was just doing that to get my cardio in. In 
any case, I&#39;m not a fucking Watergate burglar,

I made it quite clear on my resume that I&#39;m 
most qualified in minotaur pube wrangling,

so eventually some quests to journey across 
the land popped up and I set off on those.

And a &quot;journey&quot; they certainly were. The ancient 
architects of our fabled land had apparently never

heard of walkable towns, so every trip to anywhere 
outside the capital city was a lengthy slog,

and fast travel is locked behind an uncommon 
consumable. Which on the one hand is good,

a quest is supposed to be an arduous trek 
full of mini-encounters and exploration,

but on the other hand it&#39;s slightly spoiled 
knowing I could acquire fast travel tokens

easily were I to complete the sidequest 
&quot;journey to the end of the credit card number.&quot;

But I don&#39;t wanna harp on the micropayment 
bollocks, that always smacked to me of the

publishing department going &quot;hey what we can chop 
out and sell for extra dosh&quot; and the developers

going &quot;I dunno, this this and this&quot; and nobody 
giving it the slightest additional thought, so

let&#39;s harp on the combat a bit instead. Because I 
found it disappointingly easy. Possibly &#39;cos I was

playing as a rogue, which meant I had one ability 
to pull enemies off balance with a grappling hook,

and a separate ability to critical strike 
enemies who have been pulled off balance,

so already we&#39;ve removed what little chance 
the infinitely repeated goblin enemies have,

but then there was my third ability to 
basically do a Sonic the Hedgehog jump

and stab the enemy nineteen million times. 
I hear magic users have a harder time of

it &#39;cos preparing spells entails standing in 
the middle of the battlefield with your magic

scepter and orbs dangling out of your trousers 
for a few seconds, but if you didn&#39;t instantly

pick the class who starts with two free knives 
then I don&#39;t have time to explain economics to

you. Not that the game was a cakewalk, some of 
the boss fights presented a difficulty spike.

In fact I was dying to one a couple of times, 
and quicker with each attempt, and I wondered

why until I noticed that every time I reloaded 
a save a big chunk of my max health was getting

cut off. Yeah, that&#39;s going to help a struggling 
player, isn&#39;t it, telling them to try again but

this time with their legs hacked off at the knee. 
Do you even know what the word &quot;save&quot; means &#39;cos

I&#39;m feeling distinctly un-saved by this feature. 
Whatever, the game also had an option to return

to the last inn save, so I figured, fuck it, I&#39;ll 
tank the walk back, but when the screen faded back

in I was like &quot;What? Where the fuck&#39;s this? This 
isn&#39;t the last inn I saved at! This was like four

or five hours ago. Oh no. Oh no no no don&#39;t 
you fucking autosave you single save slotted

slattern FUCK. I took a moment then, staring at 
my character&#39;s twitching buttocks, contemplating

the afternoon I&#39;d just had stolen from me, and 
eventually reached my conclusion: Suck a dick,

Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2. You weren&#39;t much fun and you&#39;ve 
got all the personality of a wooden cutting board

in unflattering underpants, so inhale the nearest 
convenient phallus to hand. Gosh, that&#39;s always

liberating to say, especially when you know you 
can spend the rest of the work week breaking in

your new inflatable sex doll. Which, you&#39;ll be 
interested to hear, Capcom, has three slots.
[Outro Music]

This video is sponsored by 
Incogni. As Socrates once said,

&quot;All I know is that I know nothing.&quot; The most 
powerful phrase in the English language is &quot;I

don&#39;t know.&quot; It is the starting point of all 
education, all self-improvement, all science,

and it&#39;s very gratifying to hear spam advertisers 
say it when they say &quot;I don&#39;t know... your email

address.&quot; And that&#39;s exactly the service that 
Incogni can provide for you. All I had to do

was set it up through its intuitive onboarding 
process and dashboard and watch it go as it

contacted hundreds of data harvesters on my behalf 
and strongly advised them to lose my details. Soon

I was saying &quot;I don&#39;t know... what it&#39;s like 
to get lots of spam email.&quot; And through Second

Wind you can get 60% off an annual Incogni plan 
so that you too can be saying &quot;I don&#39;t know...

why I didn&#39;t take this offer sooner.&quot; Just use 
code secondwind at incogni.com/secondwind. Just

use code secondwind at incogni.com/secondwind. 
Why&#39;d you say it twice, Yahtzee? I DON&#39;T KNOW!
